project.name: Kiwi.js
project.description: Kiwi.js is a Javascript/Typescript library for creating HTML5 games.

Tweens.name: Tweens
Tweens.description: The section of Kiwi which holds the scripts that manage Tween's in Kiwi. The scripts in this section are based on Tween.js by sole and have been converted to TypeScript and integrated into Kiwi. https://github.com/sole/tween.js

Easing.name: Easing
Easing.description: Contains various methods that can be used when you are wanting to ease a Tween.

Animations.name: Animations
Animations.description: Is the namespace in which all code that is used to create/provide an animation of various sorts are stored. These could range from animations that change the cell of a SpriteSheet that is displayed every few seconds (Animation/Sequence), to animations that change a numeric value on a object over a period time (Tweens).

Kiwi.name: Kiwi
Kiwi.description:
Module - Kiwi (Core)
The top level namespace in which all core classes and modules are defined.

Components.name: Components
Components.description: Component's are a snipnets of code which are designed to provide extra functionality to various objects, such as IChild's/GameObjects/HUDWidgets/e.t.c. The code that components have are not necessarily needed for an object to work, but are instead provided to make common task's that you would do with those objects easier. An Example being that at times you may like to make a GameObject draggable by the user and so you can then add Input Component and execute the enableDrag on that GameObject. That would be task that not every GameObject would need, but only specific ones.

Files.name: Files
Files.description: Holds a reference to all of the data Files (json, xml, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State that this DataLibrary is on.

GameObjects.name: GameObjects
GameObjects.description: The GameObject namespace holds classes which are designed to be added to a State (either directly, or as an ancestor of a Group) and are the Objects that are used when wanting to render anything visual onto the current State. Each GameObject is a representation of a particular item in a game and as such has information that corresponds to that item (like where they are in the 'GameWorld', the scale of the GameObject, who their parent is, e.t.c). For Example: If you wanted to have a massive background image then you can use the StaticImage GameObject, as that is a relatively light-weight object). Or if you had Player with an Animation, which user's could interactive with, then you would use a Sprite, which is more robust.

Tilemap.name: Tilemap
Tilemap.description: An area of the GameObjects section which deals specifically with the use of TileMap or items related with TileMaps.

Geom.name: Geom
Geom.description: Contains common classes whose applications deal with geometry or the collision of geometric shapes.

HUD.name: HUD
HUD.description:
The HUD (Heads Up Display) is a section that handles the displayment of information that you always want visible to user. 
This section is managed differently to normal GameObjects, where the difference being that HUD items aren't added to a Canvas but are DOM elements instead. Since they DOM elements you can style these elements using a CSS sheet if you wish.

HUDComponents.name: HUDComponents
HUDComponents.description: HUDComponents are a space where components that are specific to HUDWidgets are kept. This are seperated from the normal Components section as the implementation of these are unique and only make sense when implemented on HUDWidgets, otherwise the concepts behind these are the same as normal Components.

Widget.name: Widget
Widget.description:
HUD Widgets are objects that are generally placed on to a HUD Display for displaying and managing information that the user would always need to see.
An example of such information would be: the Health remaining, amount of ammo left, time they have left, e.t.c.
And each one of those examples would have its own widget.

Input.name: Input
Input.description: Section that contains the code related to handling user interaction with a game.

Renderers.name: Renderers
Renderers.description: Contains the classes which are related to the rendering of GameObjects.

Sound.name: Sound
Sound.description: The namespace that holds all of the assets and functionality when dealing with Audio.

Textures.name: Textures
Textures.description: Contains Objects that are used when dealing specifically with Textures/Images. Majority of these classes are for Internal Kiwi use.

Time.name: Time
Time.description: Contains ways of tracking time within a game or application. Each game will have a ClockManager, MasterClock and a single Clock automatically generated for them upon game creation.

Utils.name: Utils
Utils.description: Utils is a space that holds a wide varity of useful methods.

Tween.name: Tween
Tween.description:
Manages the tweening of properties/values on a single object. A Tween is the animation of a number between an initially value to and final value (that you specify). 
Note: When using a Tween you need to make sure that the Tween has been added to a TweenManager. You can either do this by creating the Tween via the Manager or alternatively using the 'add' method on the TweenManager. Otherwise the tween will not work.

Based on tween.js by sole. Converted to TypeScript and integrated into Kiwi.
https://github.com/sole/tween.js

params.name: object
params.description: The object that this tween is taking affect on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this tween is for.

Tween.author: egraether / http://egraether.com/

TweenManager.name: TweenManager
TweenManager.description:
The TweenManager is automatically created on every game. This class is responsible for the creation and management of tweens for the game.
 
Based on tween.js by sole. Converted to TypeScript and integrated into Kiwi.
https://github.com/sole/tween.js
TweenManager.author: egraether / http://egraether.com/

Animation.name: Animation
Animation.description:
An Animation contains information about a single animation that is held on a AnimationManager. 
The information that is held is unique to this individual animation and will initially be the same as a Sequence,
but if you do ever modify the information held in this Animation the corresponding Sequence will not be updated.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this anim.

params.name: sequences
params.description: The sequence that this anim will be using to animate.

params.name: clock
params.description: A game clock that this anim will be using to keep record of the time between frames.

params.name: parent
params.description: The animation manager that this animation belongs to.

Sequence.name: Sequence
Sequence.description:
A Sequence is a series of cells that are held on a SpriteSheet/TextureAtlas.
Sequences are generally used with the AnimationManager/Animation sections as a way to initially create Animations on GameObjects that use the same TextureAtlas.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this sequence. This is not unique.

params.name: cells
params.description: The cells that are in this animation.

params.name: speed
params.description: The time an animation should spend on each frame.

params.name: loop
params.description: If the sequence should play again if it was animating and the animation reaches the last frame.

AnimationManager.name: AnimationManager
AnimationManager.description:
The AnimationManager is used to handle the creation and playment of Animations on a individual GameObject based on the TextureAtlas it has. 
When the AnimationManager is instantiated it will loop through all of the Sequences on the TextureAtlas of the GameObject being used and will create a new Animation for each one.
Now when you create a new Animation that animation will automatically be added as a new Sequence to the corresponding Texture. 
This way you don't need to create new Animations for a each Sprite that use's the same Texture.

params.name: entity
params.description: The entity that this animation component belongs to.

ArcadePhysics.name: ArcadePhysics
ArcadePhysics.description:
Ported from Flixel, most functions operation identically to the original flixel functions, though some
have been split into multiple functions. Generally where functions originally accepted
either groups or gameobjects within the same argument, the ported functions one or the other.
http://www.flixel.org/
http://www.adamatomic.com/
ArcadePhysics.author: Adam 'Atomic' Saltsman, Flixel

Box.name: Box
Box.description:
The Box Component is used to handle the various 'bounds' that each GameObject has. 
There are FOUR different types of bounds (each one is a rectangle) on each box depending on what you are wanting:
RawBounds: The bounding box of the GameObject before rotation.
RawHitbox: The hitbox of the GameObject before rotation. This can be modified to be different than the normal bounds but if not specified it will be the same as the raw bounds.
Bounds: The bounding box of the GameObject after rotation.
Hitbox: The hitbox of the GameObject after rotation. If you modified the raw hitbox then this one will be modified as well, otherwise it will be the same as the normal bounds.

params.name: parent
params.description: The entity that this box belongs to.

params.name: x
params.description: Its position on the x axis

params.name: y
params.description: Its position on the y axis

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the box.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the box.

Input.name: Input
Input.description:
The Input Component is used on GameObjects in which the user may interactive with via a Mouse or Touch 
and as such this class contains useful methods and callbacks you can subscribe to. 
By default the Input component is disabled (this is because when enabled the input component can be process intensive) 
but you can enabled it yourself (which is recommened) BUT in case you forget the input component will automagically 
be enabled once you access a Signal on this class.

params.name: owner
params.description: The IChild that owns this Input.

params.name: box
params.description: The box that is to be used for the event firing.

params.name: enabled
params.description: If this input component should be enabled or not.

Sound.name: Sound
Sound.description: The Sound Component is a class to assist with the creation and management of multiple pieces of audio that may exist on a single Entity. This class is NOT needed when dealing with audio but is instead provided to assist in dealing with audio.

params.name: parent
params.description: Who the sound component belongs to.

Camera.name: Camera
Camera.description: A Camera is used to render a particular section of the game world on the stage. Each Camera has a coordinates which are held in the transform property, and a width/height. Note: This class should never be directly instantiated but instead should be made through a CameraManager's 'create' method.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this camera belongs to.

params.name: id
params.description: A unique ID for this camera

params.name: name
params.description: The name this camera goes by

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinate of the camera

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinate of the camera

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the camera

params.name: height
params.description: The cameras height

CameraManager.name: CameraManager
CameraManager.description: Used to handle the creation and management of Cameras on a Game. Each Game will always have created for it a CameraManager and a default Camera on the manager. More Cameras can always be created by used of the create method of a CameraManager.

Component.name: Component
Component.description: The base class that all components extend from and thus contains all of the common functionality that is required of every Component.

params.name: owner
params.description: The IChild that this component belongs to.

params.name: componentName
params.description: The name of this component.

ComponentManager.name: ComponentManager
ComponentManager.description:
The component manager is a class that is used to handle a number of components that are active on a particular object.
This way if you want to check to see if a particular component is on an object you can ask the component manager, 
Or when updating components you can tell the component manager to update and all of the components will update as well.

params.name: type
params.description: - The type of object that this component manager's owner is.

params.name: owner
params.description: - The owner of this component manager.

Entity.name: Entity
Entity.description:
An Entity serves as a container for game objects to extend from and thus you should never directly instantiate this class.
Each Entity has a unique ID (UID) which is automatically generated upon instantiation.
Every entity requires that you pass to it the state that it belongs too, that way when you switch states the appropriate entitys can be deleted.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this entity belongs to. Used to generate the Unique ID and for garbage collection.

params.name: x
params.description: The entities position on the x axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The entities position on the y axis.

Game.name: Game
Game.description: The base class that is used when you are wanting to create a new Game. Handles the initialisation of all of the various individual game managers and holds the RAF which is used for the game loop.

params.name: domParent
params.description: The ID of a DOM element that the game should use as its 'container'. If you are targeting Cocoon then you don't need to worry about this and can leave it blank.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the game that is being created.

params.name: state
params.description: The state to load initially. This can either be the name of a state, or the state object itself.

params.name: options
params.description: Any special options for the game. E.g. Is DEBUG_ON or DEBUG_OFF, RENDERER_CANVAS or RENDERER_WEBGL, TARGET_BROWSER or TARGET_COCOON

Group.name: Group
Group.description: Is a class the implements the IChild structure who's purpose is to contain multiple children/members, those of which also implement the IChild interface. The members of the Group's coordinates are also in relation to the Group that they were added to. So if you moved an entire Group, each member of that Group would also 'move'.

params.name: state
params.description: The State that this Group is a part of.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this group.

IChild.name: IChild
IChild.description:
A IChild is an Interface (defined as a class as the documentation does not support Interfaces just yet),
which outlines the methods/properties that objects which are intended to be added as a child of a Stage or Group must have in order to work.

params.name: game
params.description: The state that this entity belongs to. Used to generate the Unique ID and for garbage collection.

params.name: plugins
params.description: The entities position on the x axis.

Signal.name: Signal
Signal.description:
A TypeScript conversion of JS Signals by Miller Medeiros.
Released under the MIT license
http://millermedeiros.github.com/js-signals/
Signal.author: Miller Medeiros, JS Signals

SignalBinding.name: SignalBinding
SignalBinding.description:
An object that represents a binding between a Signal and a listener function.
Released under the MIT license
http://millermedeiros.github.com/js-signals/
SignalBinding.author: Miller Medeiros, JS Signals

params.name: signal
params.description: Reference to Signal object that listener is currently bound to.

params.name: listener
params.description: Handler function bound to the signal.

params.name: isOnce
params.description: If binding should be executed just once.

params.name: listenerContext
params.description: Context on which listener will be executed (object that should represent the `this` variable inside listener function).

params.name: priority
params.description: The priority level of the event listener. (default = 0).

Stage.name: Stage
Stage.description:
Each game contains a single Stage which controls the creation of the elements required for a Kiwi game to work. 
Such as the Canvas and the rendering contexts, as well as the width/height of the game and the position it should be on the screen.

StateManager.name: StateManager
StateManager.description: The state manager handles the starting, parsing, looping and swapping of game states. Thus there is only ever one state manager per game.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this statemanager belongs to.

DataLibrary.name: DataLibrary
DataLibrary.description: Holds a reference to all of the data Files (json, xml, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State that this DataLibrary is on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this DataLibrary belongs to.

File.name: File
File.description: Handles the loading of an external data file via a tag loader or xhr + arraybuffer, and optionally saves to the file store.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this file belongs to.

params.name: dataType
params.description: The type of file that is being loaded. For this you can use the STATIC properties that are located on this class for quick code completion.

params.name: path
params.description: The location of the file that is to be loaded.

params.name: name
params.description: A name for the file. If no name is specified then the files name will be used.

params.name: saveToFileStore
params.description: If the file should be saved on the file store or not.

params.name: storeAsGlobal
params.description: If this file should be stored as a global file, or if it should be destroyed when this state gets switched out.

FileStore.name: FileStore
FileStore.description: Holds all of the Files (regardless of the file type) that have been loaded throughout a game/are accessable at a particular point in time. Contains methods for dealing with files. Note: Each time the state is switched the file store will remove all references to files that have not been flagged as global.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this FileStore belongs to.

Loader.name: Loader
Loader.description: Used for the loading of files and game assets. This usually happens when a State is at the 'loading' stage (executing the 'preload' method).

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this loader belongs to.

TileMapLayer.name: TileMapLayer
TileMapLayer.description: Maintains information about a single two dimensional TileMap (saved in the property mapData) and is created on TileMap. This class should generally never be directly instantiated as the creation of TileMapLayers are handled through a TileMap.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this tilemap belongs to.

params.name: parent
params.description: The TileMap on which this TileMapLayer is a part of.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The spritesheet that is being used to render the tiles.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this tilemap.

params.name: tileWidth
params.description: The width of a single tile.

params.name: tileHeight
params.description: The height of a single tile

Tile.name: Tile
Tile.description: A single Tile that exists on the mapData property inside of a TileMapLayer. A Tile should never be directly created by a user but instead reference through its TileMapLayer which would have created it. Each Tile has an ArcadePhysics component that can be used for collision detection.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this Tile is on.

params.name: tileLayer
params.description: The TileMapLayer that this Tile is a part of.

params.name: tileTypes
params.description: The type of tile that this is.

params.name: width
params.description: The width of this tile.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of this tile.

params.name: x
params.description: The tiles x coordinate.

params.name: y
params.description: The tiles y coordinate.

TileMap.name: TileMap
TileMap.description: A GameObject that can be used when wanting to generate and use TileMaps in a game and the job of it is to handle the creation and management of TileMapLayers/Tiles on the whole map. Each TileMap (once created) will contain at least one TileMapLayer, which will hold the information about the map generated, but more TileMapLayers can be generated on a single TileMap.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this Tilemap is on.

TileType.name: TileType
TileType.description: Defines a particular type of tile that is used on a TileMap. A TileType object should never be directly instantiated by a developer, but instead referenced through the TileMap that it belongs to. A new TileType is created for each cell that exists on the SpriteSheet that is parse when creating a TileMap. Note: There is always a TileType (at index of -1) generated which you can use when no tile will be placed in that spot.

params.name: gmae
params.description: The game that this type of tile belongs to.

params.name: tilemap
params.description: The TileMap that this type of tile is on.

params.name: index
params.description: The unique index that this tile has associated with it.

params.name: width
params.description: The width of this tile. Only used for collision detection.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of this tile. Only used for collision detection.

Sprite.name: Sprite
Sprite.description: A Sprite is a general purpose GameObject that contains majority of the functionality that is needed/would be wanted and as such should be used only when you are wanting a GameObject with a lot of interaction. When creating a Sprite you pass to it as TextureAtlas (for the image you want to render), now if that Texture Atlas isn't a SINGLE_IMAGE then the Sprite will have an AnimationManager Component to handle any SpriteSheet animations you need.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this sprite belongs to

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture you want to apply to this entity

params.name: x
params.description: The sprites initial coordinates on the x axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The sprites initial coordinates on the y axis.

params.name: enableInput
params.description: If the input component should be enabled or not.

StaticImage.name: StaticImage
StaticImage.description: A light weight game object for displaying static images that would have little or no interaction with other GameObjects. An Example of this would be a background image. Note: Since a StaticImage is lightweight it doesn't have any AnimationManager to handle the switching of cells (If you were using a SpriteSheet/TextureAtlas). In order to switch cells you can change the value of the cellIndex property.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this static image belongs to

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture atlas to use as the image.

params.name: x
params.description: Its coordinates on the x axis

params.name: y
params.description: The coordinates on the y axis

Textfield.name: Textfield
Textfield.description: Textfield is a GameObject that is used when you are wanting to render text onto the current State. The Textfield is not designed to have any interaction with other GameObjects and as such it does not have many (if any) components or even a width/height.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this Textfield belongs to

params.name: text
params.description: The text that is contained within this textfield.

params.name: x
params.description: The new x coordinate from the Position component

params.name: y
params.description: The new y coordinate from the Position component

params.name: color
params.description: The color of the text.

params.name: size
params.description: The size of the text in pixels.

params.name: weight
params.description: The weight of the text.

params.name: fontFamily
params.description: The font family that is to be used when rendering.

params.name: optimize
params.description: If Kiwi should optimise the rendering of the text. Disabled by default if targetting CocoonJS.

AABB.name: AABB
AABB.description: An object representation of an axis-aligned bounding box.

Circle.name: Circle
Circle.description: A Circle object is an area defined by its position, as indicated by its center point (x,y) and diameter.

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

params.name: diameter
params.description: The diameter of the circle.

Intersect.name: Intersect
Intersect.description: A collection of methods to help determine and return intersection between geometric objects.

IntersectResult.name: IntersectResult
IntersectResult.description: A light result object to hold the results of an intersection

Line.name: Line
Line.description: A line object is an infinte line through space. The two sets of x/y coordinates define the Line Segment.

params.name: [x1
params.description: = 0]  x1 x component of first point.

params.name: [y1
params.description: = 0] y1 y component of first point.

params.name: [x2
params.description: = 0] x2 x component of second point.

params.name: [y2
params.description: = 0] y2 y component of second point.

Matrix.name: Matrix
Matrix.description:
Represents a 2d transformation matrix. This can be used to map points between different coordinate spaces. Matrices are used
by Transform objects to represent translation, scale and rotation transformations, and to determine where objects are in world space or camera space.
Objects such as entities and groups may be nested, and their associated transforms may represent how they are scaled, translated and rotated relative to a parent
transform.
By concatenating an object's transformatkion matrix with it's ancestors matrices, it is possible to determine the absolute position of the object in world space.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformation_matrix#Examples_in_2D_graphics for an in depth discussion of 2d tranformation matrices.

params.name: [a
params.description: = 1]   position 0,0 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [b
params.description: = 0]   position 0,1 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [c
params.description: = 0]   position 1,0 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [d
params.description: = 1]   position 1,1 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [tx
params.description: = 0]   position 2,0 of the matrix, affects translation on x axis.

params.name: [ty
params.description: = 0]   position 2,1 of the matrix, affects translation on y axis.

Point.name: Point
Point.description: Represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.

params.name: x
params.description: x One-liner. Default is ?.

params.name: y
params.description: y One-liner. Default is ?.

Ray.name: Ray
Ray.description: Represents a halfline. The ray starts at the first point and extends infinitely in the direction of the second.

params.name: x1
params.description: x1

params.name: y1
params.description: y1

params.name: x2
params.description: x2

params.name: y2
params.description: y2

Rectangle.name: Rectangle
Rectangle.description: An area defined by its position, as indicated by its top-left corner (x,y) and width and height

params.name: x
params.description: x The x coordinate of the top-left corner of the rectangle.

params.name: y
params.description: y The y coordinate of the top-left corner of the rectangle.

params.name: width
params.description: width The width of the rectangle in pixels.

params.name: height
params.description: height The height of the rectangle in pixels.

Transform.name: Transform
Transform.description:
Represents position, scale, rotation and rotationPoint of an Entity.
- Values can be transformed with a 3x3 affine transformation matrix, which each transform is assigned.
- A tranform can be assigned a parent, which may in turn have it's own parent, thereby creating a tranform inheritence heirarchy
- A concatenated transformation matrix, representing the combined matrices of the transform and its ancestors.

params.name: x
params.description: x. X position of the transform.

params.name: y
params.description: y. Y position of the transform.

params.name: scaleX
params.description: scaleX. X scaling of the transform.

params.name: scaleY
params.description: scaleY. Y scaling of the transform.

params.name: rotation
params.description: rotation. Rotation of the transform in radians.

params.name: rotX
params.description: rotX. rotationPoint offset on X axis.

params.name: rotY
params.description: rotY. rotationPoint offset on Y axis.

Vector2.name: Vector2
Vector2.description: A two dimensional vector object for storing and manipulating x and y vector components.

Counter.name: Counter
Counter.description:
The Counter component handles a incrementation/decrementation of a singular numeric value. 
You can also specifiy maximum/minimum values that the numeric value has be within but by default there is no max/min.

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this Component belongs to.

params.name: current
params.description: The current value.

params.name: max
params.description: The maximum value it can be. Default is null which means no maximum.

params.name: min
params.description: The minimum value that the current can be. Default is null which means no minium.

Time.name: Time
Time.description:
A subclass of TextField which manages the displaying of a Time/Timer by creating a new clock on the Time Manager.
The time is managed by a Time Component which contains a format property that handles how the time should be formatted.

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this component belongs to.

params.name: format
params.description: The format that the time is to be displayed in. Leave blank for the default time.

WidgetInput.name: WidgetInput
WidgetInput.description:
The WidgetInput Component handles the input events that you may want to listen to on a widget.
This Component is essentually another version of the normal Input Component but instead of for GameObjects this is for HUDWidgets.

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this WidgetInput belongs to.

params.name: container
params.description: The HTMLElement that the events will occur on/to.

Bar.name: Bar
Bar.description:
Used for displaying of information in a bar like of format. Example: Amount of health remaining for a character.
This class creates a 'innerbar' div inside of its main container which you can apply styles to.
You can control the minimum/maximum and current values of the bar through the Counter widget.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this bar belongs to.

params.name: current
params.description: The current value of the bar.

params.name: max
params.description: The maximum value that there can be.

params.name: x
params.description: The coordinates of this widget on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The cooridnates of this widget on the y-axis.

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the widget. Defaults to 120.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the widget. Defaults to 20.

params.name: color
params.description: The default color of the inner bar. Defaults to #000 (black).

BasicScore.name: BasicScore
BasicScore.description:
A subclass of textfield that is primarily used to keep track of a score.
The score can be accessed via the counter component.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this BasicScore belongs to.

params.name: x
params.description: The cooridnates of the game on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The cooridnates of the game on the y-axis.

params.name: initial
params.description: The initial score to start off at.

Button.name: Button
Button.description: A subclass of the TextField that has its own input component so that you can listen for mouse events on this widget.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this belongs to.

params.name: text
params.description: The text that you want to display inside the button.

params.name: x
params.description: The x-coordnates of this Widget.

params.name: y
params.description: The y-coordinates of this Widget.

Icon.name: Icon
Icon.description:
Used to display a cell from a TextureAtlas in the HUD. This could be used for portraits of the character, e.t.c.
You can change the current cell that is being used in the TextureAtlas by modifing the cellIndex property.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this icon belongs to.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The image that you would like displayed.

params.name: x
params.description: The coordinate of the icon on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: {number The coordinate of the icon on the y-axis.

IconBar.name: IconBar
IconBar.description:
The IconBar used to display a series of icons which represent a number of 'something' the user may have. 
Example: If you had a shooter style game you might want to display the amount of 'ammo' left in the gun using a series of bullet icons. You could then use this IconBar to display that series.
The amount is based of a counter components current value, so you can set a maximum and minimum number of images to be displayed.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this icon bar belongs to.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture atlas that the icons will have.

params.name: current
params.description: The current amount of icons in the bar.

params.name: max
params.description: The maximum number of icons.

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinates of the first icon.

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinates of the last icon.

Menu.name: Menu
Menu.description:
A Widget for that is used for the management/displaying of a Menu. 
This class is primarily used as a manager of MenuItems, so on this class you can create/add MenuItems
and styles that you want applyed to all MenuItems.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this Menu belongs to.

params.name: x
params.description: Its position on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: Its position on the y -axis.

MenuItem.name: MenuItem
MenuItem.description:
A MenuItem extends the Button Widget and is typically contained inside of a Menu Widget. 
Since a MenuItem extends the Button Widget you can access the Input Component that it has to listen to mouse events.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this MenuItem belongs to.

params.name: text
params.description: The text that is to be inside the menuitem.

params.name: x
params.description: The position of this menu item on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The position of this menu item on the y-axis.

TextField.name: TextField
TextField.description:
A Widget that is used for the displaying of text on the HUD. 
Foreach TextField you can add some prefix/suffix text, which is more useful on classes extending this one.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this textfield belongs to.

params.name: text
params.description: The text on this textfield.

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinates

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinates

HUDDisplay.name: HUDDisplay
HUDDisplay.description:
A HUDDisplay is a container for which you can add/removes widget on, and is more used to manage the widgets that are being displayed on it.
A HUDDisplay is created through a games HUDManager and is NOT directly instantiated.
Each game can contain multiple HUDDisplay's and each HUDDisplay can contain multiple HUDWidgets.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this HUD Display belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this display.

HUDManager.name: HUDManager
HUDManager.description:
This class manages all of the various HUDDisplays that are currently used on this Managers game.
Using this class you can create/add and remove HUDDisplays from this game,
change the HUDDisplay that is currently being display (also known as the currentHUD) and show/hide the currentHUD.
Each HUDManager also has at least one HUDDisplay which is called the 'defaultHUD' you cannot remove,
but you can reassign the defaultHUD to be a different HUDDisplay if you want.

params.name: game
params.description: game

HUDWidget.name: HUDWidget
HUDWidget.description:
The HUDWidget is an abstract class containing the fundamental properties and methods that every HUDWidget needs to have.
This class is designed to be extended from and thus objects should not directly instantiate it.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this HUDWidget belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the type of HUDWidget.

params.name: x
params.description: The coordinates of this HUDWidget on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The coordinates of this HUDWidget on the y-axis.

Finger.name: Finger
Finger.description: Used with the Touch manager class, this object holds information about a single touch point/locaton (or you know a finger). By default a Finger has a diameter of 44 pixels (random average size of a finger) which can be used for collision/overlap detection. That value can be modified. Note: A Finger is only active whilst the user is 'pressing' down on stage.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this finger belongs to.

InputManager.name: InputManager
InputManager.description: Handles the initialization and management of the various ways a user can interact with the device/game, whether this is through a Keyboard and Mouse or by a Touch. Also contains some of the general callbacks that are 'global' between both Desktop and Mobile based devices.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this object belongs to.

Key.name: Key
Key.description: A compact object that holds the most important details about a Keyboard Event response.

params.name: manager
params.description: The keyboard manager that this key belongs to.

params.name: keycode
params.description: The keycode that this key is.

params.name: event
params.description: The keyboard event (if there was one) when this was created.

Keyboard.name: Keyboard
Keyboard.description: Handles and Manages the dispatching of keyboard events. When the user press's a button a new Key object is created.

Keycodes.name: Keycodes
Keycodes.description: A Static class which has a property associated with all all of the character codes on a typical keyboard. While you don't need this class for your game to work, it is quite handy to use as it can speed up the development process.

Mouse.name: Mouse
Mouse.description: Handles the dispatching/management of Mouse Events on a game. When this class is instantiated a MouseCursor object is also created (on this object) which holds the information that is unique to the mouse cursor, although majority of that information is still accessible inside this object.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this mouse manager belongs to.

MouseCursor.name: MouseCursor
MouseCursor.description: Holds the information about a Mouse Cursor. Such as the position of the cursor, the mouse wheels delta, the button that was used, e.t.c. Note: A mouse cursor is always active.

Pointer.name: Pointer
Pointer.description: Is a generic class that holds the properties/methods that are common across various different methods of inputs from the user, mainly between Touch and Mouse based events. This abstract class and such it is suppose to be extended from for individual implementations.

Touch.name: Touch
Touch.description: Handles the dispatching and management of touch based events for the game. When the Touch manager is created TEN finger objects are created and used when the user interacts with the screen. Those finger are what you can use to create games that make the most out of multitouch events.

params.name: game
params.description: the game that this touch manager belongs to.

IRenderer.name: IRenderer
IRenderer.description:
A IRenderer is an Interface (defined as a class as the documentation does not support Interfaces just yet),
which outlines the methods/properties that are required any Renderer.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this canvas renderer belongs to.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this renderer belongs to.

Audio.name: Audio
Audio.description: A Object that contains the functionality needed when wanting to play a single sound/sound file on a game.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this piece of audio belongs to.

params.name: key
params.description: The key to which which piece of audio should be loaded from the AudioLibrary.

params.name: volume
params.description: A number between 0 (silence) and 1 (loud).

params.name: loop
params.description: If the audio should loop when it is finished or just stop.

AudioLibrary.name: AudioLibrary
AudioLibrary.description: Holds a reference to all of the Audio Files (mp3, ogg, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State that this AudioLibrary is on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this audio library is a member of.

AudioManager.name: AudioManager
AudioManager.description: Manages the initialisation of assets necessary when dealing with audio in the game, either through Audio Tags or the Web Audio API. Also provides global sound controls that will be applyed to all Audio objects at the same time.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this audio manager belongs to.

Bootstrap.name: Bootstrap
Bootstrap.description: DOM Boot and Ready functions (based on those used by jQuery)

Browser.name: Browser
Browser.description:
Gets the x/y coordinate offset of any given valid DOM Element from the top/left position of the browser
Based on jQuery offset https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/offset.js

Device.name: Device
Device.description:
Detects device support capabilities. Using some elements from System.js by MrDoob and Modernizr
https://github.com/Modernizr/Modernizr/blob/master/feature-detects/audio.js
Device.author: Modernizr team

SingleImage.name: SingleImage
SingleImage.description: A special type of TextureAtlas that is used when the user has loaded a single image. This type of TextureAtlas contains only one cell which is generally the whole width/height of the image and starts at the coordinates 0/0. A SingleImage has a space to store sequences but this will not be used.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the single image

params.name: image
params.description: the image that is being used.

params.name: width
params.description: the width of the image

params.name: height
params.description: the height of the image

params.name: offsetX
params.description: the offset of the image on the x axis. Useful if the image has a border that you don't want to show.

params.name: offsetY
params.description: the offset of the image of the y axis. Useful if the image has a border that you don't want to show.

SpriteSheet.name: SpriteSheet
SpriteSheet.description: A special type of TextureAtlas that is created when loading in images that are design to be SpriteSheets. A SpriteSheet will generally contain multiple cells and can also contain sequences which are then automatically added as Animations when this texture is used on a Sprite.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the spritesheet.

params.name: texture
params.description: The image that is being used for the spritesheet.

params.name: cellWidth
params.description: The width of a single cell.

params.name: cellHeight
params.description: The height of a single cell.

params.name: numCells
params.description: The number of cells in total.

params.name: rows
params.description: The number of cells that make up a row.

params.name: cols
params.description: The number of cells that make up a column.

params.name: sheetOffsetX
params.description: The offset of the whole sheet on the x axis. Useful if the image has a border you don't want to show.

params.name: sheetOffsetY
params.description: The offset of the whole sheet on the y axis. Useful if the image has a border you don't want to show.

params.name: cellOffsetX
params.description: An offset between cells on the x axis. Useful if there is a border between cells which is not to be shown.

params.name: cellOffsetY
params.description: An offset between cells on the y axis. Useful if there is a border between cells which is not to be shown.

TextureAtlas.name: TextureAtlas
TextureAtlas.description: A TextureAtlas is the base class that is created for each image that is loaded in through Kiwi. Each TextureAtlas contains a name (the same as the key that the user chose when loading the image in),the HTMLImageElement that it is for and a number of cells.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the texture atlas. This is usually defined by the developer when loading the assets.

params.name: type
params.description: The type of texture atlas that this is. There are currently only three types.

params.name: cells
params.description: The cells that are within this image..

params.name: image
params.description: The image that the texture atlas is using.

params.name: sequences
params.description: Any sequences of cells for this texture atlas. Used for animation.

TextureLibrary.name: TextureLibrary
TextureLibrary.description: Holds a reference to all of the image files (jpg, png, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State this TextureLibrary is on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this texture library belongs to.

Clock.name: Clock
Clock.description:
The Clock class offers a way of tracking time within a game. When creating a new Clock you should NOT directly instantiate this class but instead use the addClock method on a ClockManager.
- The MasterClock is a property of the Kiwi.Time.Manager class and tracks real world time in milliseconds elapsed since the application started. This happens automatically and there is no need to do anything to set this up.
- An instance of a clock is used to track time in arbitrary units (milliseconds by default)
- A clock can be started, paused, unpaused and stopped. Once stopped, re-starting the clock again will reset it.
- Any number of timers can be attached to a clock. See the Kiwi.Time.Timer class for timer details.
- If the clock is paused, any timers attached to the clock will take this into account and not continue to fire events until the clock is unpaused.
(Note that this is not the same as pausing timers, which can be done manually and needs to be undone manually.)

params.name: manager
params.description: The ClockManager that this clock belongs to. .

params.name: master
params.description: The MasterClock that it is getting the time in relation to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the clock.

params.name: units
params.description: The units that this clock is to operate in.

ClockManager.name: ClockManager
ClockManager.description: Handles the generation and tracking of Clocks and Time related applications for a single game.

MasterClock.name: MasterClock
MasterClock.description:
The MasterClock tracks time elapsed since the application started.
Each ClockManager has only one MasterClock which is automatically generated when the game initially booted.
You should not access it directly, use the Clock and Timer classes instead.

Timer.name: Timer
Timer.description:
The Timer class hooks into a game Clock and allows you run code at a specified point in game time.
Use the start() method to start a timer. Add TimerEvents to set-up code to be run on the timer interval.
Timer objects can run once or repeat at specified intervals to execute code on a schedule.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the timer.

params.name: clock
params.description: The game clock instance this Timer is based on.

params.name: delay
params.description: The number of clock units to wait between firing events.

params.name: repeatCount
params.description: The number of times to repeat the timer before it is expired. If you don't want it to ever expire, set a value of -1.

TimerEvent.name: TimerEvent
TimerEvent.description: A TimerEvent hooks into a Timer and is an object that is generated when you are wanting to executed a callback at a specific point in time.

params.name: type
params.description: The type of TimerEvent that this is.

params.name: callback
params.description: The method that is to be executed when the event occurs.

params.name: context
params.description: The context that the callback is to be called in.

Canvas.name: Canvas
Canvas.description: Creates and the manages a Canvas DOMElement.

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the canvas.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the canvas.

params.name: visible
params.description: If the canvas is visible or not.

params.name: offScreen
params.description: If the canvas is designed to be offscreen or not.

Common.description:
Methods to assist in working with Structs.

GameMath.name: GameMath
GameMath.description:
Adds a set of extra Math functions and extends a few commonly used ones.
Includes some methods written by Dylan Engelman.
GameMath.author: Dylan Engelman

RandomDataGenerator.name: RandomDataGenerator
RandomDataGenerator.description:
Manages the creation of unique internal game IDs.
Based on Nonsense by Josh Faul https://github.com/jocafa/Nonsense
Random number generator from http://baagoe.org/en/wiki/Better_random_numbers_for_javascript
RandomDataGenerator.author: Josh Faul

RequestAnimationFrame.name: RequestAnimationFrame
RequestAnimationFrame.description: Abstracts away the use of RAF or setTimeout for the core game update loop. The callback can be re-mapped on the fly.

GameManager.name: GameManager
GameManager.description: The GameManager is used to maintain mulitple instances of Kiwi games within a single document.

Note: This method will be dispatching events EVERY time the cell changes, so this will include when changing/switching animations.
classitems.name: onUpdate

classitems.description:
Dispatches callbacks each time the current animation is switched NOT when the cells of a animation change.
Function's dispatched from this event have TWO parameters, 
One - Name of the animation switched to.
Two - The Animation object that is now the current.
classitems.name: onChange

classitems.description:
Either switches to a particular animation OR a particular frame in the current animation depending on if you pass the name of an animation that exists on this Manager (as a string) or a number refering to a frame index on the Animation. 
When you switch to a particular animation then 
You can also force the animation to play or to stop by passing a boolean in. But if left as null, the animation will base it off what is currently happening.
So if the animation is currently 'playing' then once switched to the animation will play. If not currently playing it will switch to and stop.
classitems.name: switchTo

params.name: play
params.description: Force the animation to play or stop. If null the animation base's it off what is currently happening.

classitems.description: Makes the current animation go to the next frame. If the animation is at the end of the sequence it then goes back to the start.
classitems.name: nextFrame

classitems.description: Makes the current animation go to the prev frame. If the animation is at the start, the animation will go the end of the sequence.

classitems.name: mass

classitems.description: The bounciness of this object.  Only affects collisions.  Default value is 0, or "not bouncy at all."

classitems.description:
How fast the speed of this object is changing.
Useful for smooth movement and gravity.

classitems.description:
This isn't drag exactly, more like deceleration that is only applied
when acceleration is not affecting the sprite.

Set the angle of a sprite to rotate it.
WARNING: rotating sprites decreases rendering
performance for this sprite by a factor of 10x!

classitems.description: If the object should seperate when it 'collides' with another object.
classitems.name: seperate

classitems.description:
Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating surface contacts.
Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here, or use touching(), justStartedTouching(), etc.
You can even use them broadly as boolean values if you're feeling saucy!
classitems.name: touching

classitems.description:
Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating surface contacts from the previous game loop step.
Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here, or use touching(), justStartedTouching(), etc.
You can even use them broadly as boolean values if you're feeling saucy!
classitems.name: wasTouching

classitems.description:
Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating collision directions.
Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here.
Useful for things like one-way platforms (e.g. allowCollisions = UP;)
The accessor "solid" just flips this variable between NONE and ANY.
classitems.name: allowCollisions

classitems.description:
Holds all of the textures that are avaiable to be accessed once this state has been loaded.
E.g. If you loaded a image and named it 'flower', once everything has loaded you can then access the flower image by saying this.textures.flower

Holds all of the audio that are avaiable to be accessed once this state has been loaded.
E.g. If you loaded a piece of audio and named it 'lazerz', once everything has loaded you can then access the lazers (pew pew) by saying this.audio.lazerz

params.description: If the image should be deleted when switching to another state or if the other states should still be able to access this image.

params.description: The width of the image. If not passed the width will be automatically calculated.

classitems.description: Adds a new spritesheet image file that is be loaded when the state gets up to the loading all of the assets.

params.description: A key for this image so that you can access it when the loading has finished.

params.name: url
params.description: The location of the image.

params.name: frameWidth
params.description: The width of a single frame in the spritesheet

params.name: frameHeight
params.description: The height of a single frame in the spritesheet

params.name: storeAsGlobal
params.description: If the image should be deleted when switching to another state or if the other states should still be able to access this image.

params.name: numCells
params.description: The number of cells/frames that are in the spritesheet. If not specified will calculate this based of the width/height of the image.

params.name: rows
params.description: The number of cells that are in a row. If not specified will calculate this based of the width/height of the image.

params.name: cols
params.description: The number of cells that are in a column. If not specified will calculate this based of the width/height of the image.

params.name: sheetOffsetX
params.description: The offset of the whole spritesheet on the x axis.

params.name: sheetOffsetY
params.description: The offset of the whole spritesheet on the y axis.

params.name: cellOffsetX
params.description: The spacing between cells on the x axis.

params.name: cellOffsetY
params.description: The spacing between cells on the y axis.
